turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: That is correct regardless of -- of who was responsible, it is apparent I would say from the record that the threat to the public arose by a reason the existence of the strike.
And --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was there findings by either Court as to the responsibility for those acts?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: No sir.
Mr. Chief Justice, there is not.
The Supreme Court --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did they ignore them or --

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: No, the Supreme Court of Missouri expressly referred to those facts --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well what was to say this is --

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- is something about the responsibility for the --

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: Yes, yes sir.

On page 348 of the record, while the evidence is not sufficient to show that the defendants were responsible for this act to sabotage which helped to bring on the emergency, it was sufficient to prove that there was a serious and alarming interruption of utility service and the public interest, health and safety were jeopardized.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: MNow, we have to treat it then just as so though -- the union and -- and the officers involved had nothing to do with this -- with this conduct?
Do you plead it that way?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: Yes sir.
I -- I do not -- I do not say that there's anything in this record which would attribute those acts to --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: -- the union and their employees.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I ask -- I beg your pardon, I'm sorry.
Please continue.

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: I -- I do say that they arose following the strike.
And I think must necessarily have been related to the strike.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I would like to ask you this question.
These matters in just indicated or stated explain for the basis for the Governor's action, is that it?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: Yes sir, Mr. Justice Frankfurter.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What I want to know is this, would the -- would the validity of Governor's action namely that it came within the authorization of the statute was that an issue subject to Court reviews or if the Court found none of these things that they have found that the basis for asking of an injunction didn't exist, but this Court has said it in another connection as they have it I think, the jurisdiction of facts on the basis of which he's allowed to move, is that right?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: That could very well -- well that could very well be true.
In other words, this is in effect on a --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's the relevance of all the testimonies?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: All right, no I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And validate his action, is that it?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: I think to validate his action and place it in the light of the circumstances in which this particular law was applied.
In other words, this by law its terms, becomes applicable only when the Governor issues his proclamation and finding that the public health and welfare are threatened.

And I think that brings us then to the essential difference between this act and the Wisconsin Act, in that this Act is so limited and that this Act is therefore in the nature of emergency legislation, and that it is within the scope of state power despite the federal acts.
Now, in the Amalgamated case, there's no question that the Chief Justice in his opinion stated that the Wisconsin statute is not -- and was not emergency legislation.
There has been reference made to the facts which the Wisconsin Supreme Court found to exist in the Gas case in Wisconsin.
However, I think --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What did it find?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What did it find, the fact of which you're talking about?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: The -- the facts referred to here earlier by -- by the -- the appellant with respect to the emergency situation in -- in Wisconsin.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did it find that there was a situation?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: The -- yes sir.
Yes sir, that was the -- that was the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That it might be injurious to the health?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: They found this that there was a dangerous condition fraught with the possibility of infinite injury to the public.

However, I say that examination of the Wisconsin case in the light of this statement indicates that that statement is no more than a justification for the temporary restraining order without notice which was issued by the Wisconsin Court.
And that the Wisconsin statute did not require such a finding in order to call for it.
The provisions or the Wisconsin statute that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But they did make the finding.

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: They did make the findings.

And furthermore, as I read the case in this Court and the United Gas case which was considered with the Amalgamated case, there was absolutely no word of reference to the situation which the Wisconsin Court had found to exist.
In other words, I find no evidence that this Court considered those facts in determination of the United case here.
And as I say, I think that it is because the Wisconsin statute did not require the existence of those facts.
It just happened -- it just happened that the Wisconsin Act had been applied in this case to what was an emergency situation.
But that would not give validity to the Act which was applicable generally to all strikes and public utilities.
It was a just a coincidence.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I understood Mr. Ratner to say that there was a question as to whether -- whether the Governor was apprised to these facts at the time the seizure was made.
Did I misunderstand in there or is there a question of that?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: To my knowledge Mr. Chief Justice no issue has been raised as to the Governor's awareness of the facts --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Not of the facts of the strike, but I mean of all of these things that you have -- have listed this as to the dangerous conditions that had been created as a result of the -- of the strike.
Is it -- maybe -- maybe I misunderstood it, if I did well, we just forget it.

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: I -- I don't -- I -- I don't -- I say that I'm aware of no issues --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, yes.

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: -- having been raised in that regard.
Certainly the -- the validity of the Governor's action was not the questioned on the grounds of, “Governor, you didn't know anything about this -- this situation.”

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: I think that I can say that the Governor did know about the situation.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is there any -- is there any specific findings made by Governor's proclamation (Inaudible) and they appear on pages 15 through 18 in the record that's -- that's -- that's all referring (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: Yes Mr Justice Stewart.
That is the Governor's proclamation and that is the Governor's finding in the situation.
Now, we say --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But why was the finding necessary for coordination injunction assuming that they can't enjoin the peaceful strike?
Why was it -- why was it necessary for the Governor to make any kind of statement?
It didn't approve that the health of the people was being injured and was being imperiled or jeopardized by such sabotage that you mentioned.
I should suppose it ordinarily a State would have that right for that the special situation, assuming the thing it enjoined is not forbidden to it by the federal law?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: I -- I think that they would have that right Mr. Justice Black but I do not think that they would be necessarily limited to exercising it in that manner.
I think it would -- if the State has the right, it has also the right to choose the method of its exercise.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Unquestionably it does unless it's forbidden by federal law.

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: Yes sir.
But I -- I don't see that the State must have, well -- sorry about the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What I was saying, what I don't quite see the great relevance here was the Governor, here the facts or not --

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- about the condition that that's going on.

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In that state I always think ordinarily unless there's some federal law that forbids it.
Every State would have to use its court's power to presume.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, it's just part of the mediation of --

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: -- it's part of a -- it's part of the statutory procedure.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It's a part of the procedure I understand.

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: Prescribed at the Missouri statute.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But I do not see myself that the State gets anymore power from the fact that there's a statute to enjoin a peaceful strike that it would have didn't have that statute.

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: Possibly not but I think it provides a -- and orderly procedure perhaps --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I agree -- I agree to that but you finally get back to the one question as to whether it's forbidden to stop a peaceful strike by the federal act.

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: That is exactly where we return, yes sir.
And that is exactly where we get to what is the meaning of the Amalgamated case as applied to the Missouri statute.
And that is where I say --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, why is that the Missouri injunction?

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: Well, of course I would disagree with Mr. Justice Black there, because I think what we have before us here is the validity of the statute --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: robert_r_welborn
turn.label: Mr. Robert R. Welborn
turn.text: -- not the validity of the -- injunction.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
